want to squeeze that in there before I
begin I thought that this was important

gonna read this letter from front to
back so you can hear everything that's
in it it was posted to scribd as a
script document within 15 minutes of it
being posted it was already taken down
so somebody who was quick enough to grab
it throw it on Twitter this person's
name is twitter.com forward slash Nick
underscore Falco that's Nick underscore
FAL CEO so with that I'm gonna get
started it's dated for today June 6th
2018 it's from the US Senate Committee
on the judiciary its from the Honorable
Rod J Rosenstein or it's addressed to
him excuse me
so it says dear Deputy Attorney General
Rosenstein the department's reply to my
may eleventh 2018 letter seeking
information about the circumstances
surrounding Lieutenant General Michael
Flynn reported conversations with the
Russian ambassador and FBI records
related to those conversations is
insufficient the letter only recounts a
series of publicly known facts about
Lieutenant General Flynn's plea
agreement and relies on improper excuses
and refusing to provide the requested
information the committee requires this
information to fulfill its
constitutional function and its charge
under Senate rules to conduct oversight
of the Justice sorry the Department of
Justice first as you may know some of
the information was requested on a
bipartisan basis before your
confirmation the committee has waited
patiently for much more than a year
for the criminal inquiry related to
general Flynn to conclude it has been
more than five months since his guilty
plea thus there is no longer any
legitimate reason to withhold facts from
the Senate about the circumstances of
his conversations with the Russian
ambassador and his FBI interview second
the department's letter erroneously
suggests that complying with
congressional oversight would result in
quote the reality or the appearance of
political interference and a quote
pending criminal prosecution
there is no pending prosecution the
guilty plea was more than five months
ago the department's letter describes in
detail what everyone already knows
Lieutenant General Flynn admitted to the
statement of offense with the able
assistance of counsel all that remains
is for Lieutenant General Flynn to be
sentenced simply disclosing facts the
committee could not possibly interfere
with the case at this late date assuming
those facts are consistent with the
representations that prosecutors
arranged for lieutenant general Flynn to
swear into federal court if the facts
are inconsistent with the plea agreement
that would be entirely different kettle
of fish third as both the committee's
requests in the department's reply note
in the exculpatory evidence must be
turned over to defense however the
department's assurance that quote mr.
Flynn is represented by skilled and
experienced attorneys who will have
access to favorable evidence and the
government's possession in quote is not
relevant to the committee's inquiry
regardless of whether all exculpatory
evidence has already been or will be
produced to the defense Congress as has
a wholly separate independent
constitutional oversight interest in the
information it may not be in the
interests of either the defendant or the
prosecutors to disclose facts
inconsistent with the plea agreement
however it would absolutely be in the
interest of Congress and the American
people to be aware of any such can in
consistencies that may exist Congress
needs to see the underlying
evidence itself not merely the
conclusions about the evidence that
prosecutors and a defendant have agreed
to describe publicly this is no ordinary
criminal case it is at the heart of a
political firestorm over the president's
alleged statements about it - former FBI
director whom he later dismissed
Congress has a right to know the full
story and to know it now presuming that
the facts are consistent with the plea
agreement there is absolutely nothing
for the department to hide and no reason
to act like it has something to hide
resisting congressional oversight only
serves to further undermine public trust
in the department
by contrast cooperation could enhance
public trust in the department by
demonstrating that its work can
withstand independent scrutiny the lack
of transparency feeds public skepticism
about the department's actions regarding
lieutenant general Flynn and related
matters for example a summary of
Lieutenant General Flynn's intercepted
calls with the Russian ambassador
ambassador was illegally leaked to the
media presumably by a current or former
government official one of the FBI
agents who reportedly conducted the
interview of Lieutenant General Flynn
Peter struck was later removed from the
Russia investigation after his texts
demonstrated animus and bias towards mr.
Trump were uncovered additionally former
director McCabe was fired for a lack of
candor regarding a leak to the Wall
Street Journal and Lieutenant General
Flynn was an adverse witness and a
pending sexual discrimination case
against mr. McCabe at the time Mr McKay
was supervising a criminal inquiry
targeting Lieutenant General Flint
former director Comey also has made
public statements about the FBI's
actions regarding lieutenant general
Flynn on his book tour that contradict
his previous descriptions to this
committee and the House Intelligence
Committee while he was FBI director
moreover newly released information
tends to support the versions of events
former director Comey relayed to the
congressional committees according to a
memorandum drafted by the president's
attorneys the White House counsel's
office believed there was a likely no
ongoing investigation of Flynn at the
time it was briefed by the Department of
Justice about Flynn's FBI interview and
Flynn himself quote had told both White
House Counsel and the chief of staff at
least twice that the FBI agents had told
him he would not be charged in quote the
memorandum describes both incidents in
detail those incidents along with the
interactions between the department and
White House Counsel as described by the
president's attorneys do not seem to
square with the current popular
narrative thus regardless of Lieutenant
General Flynn's underlying conduct the
FBI's conduct here is ripe for
congressional oversight finally it is
disingenuous and extremely disturbing
that the department would imply that a
request to interview a fact witness such
as Special Agent Pitka
that's P ie in TKA has anything
whatsoever to do with quote allegations
against that witness as you well know
seeking information from a fact witness
is not the same thing as an allegation
of wrongdoing quite the contrary it
seems he is likely to be an objective
reliable and trustworthy witness which
is precisely why the committee would
benefit from his testimony moreover you
also know very well that I am committed
to transparency in the committee's work
and for that reason I generally post all
committee correspondents including a
request for interviews with government
witnesses on my website so that they are
publicly available
thus the department's reference to quote
committee staffers who quote choose to
release the letter is an
an inaccurate deflection from the issue
at hand if the department has a
complaint about the committee's
long-standing policy and practice of
publicly posting official correspondence
then please address it directly with me
rather than making veiled uninformed
accusations about committee staff while
I am generally unlikely to make
exceptions to my normal policy and
practice the department has always been
free to make a specific request that
certain correspondence remain private
for a period of time for a good cause
in this case it did not do so please let
me know when you will provide the
special the requested documents so that
we can begin scheduling an appointment
with special Agent P emka thank you for
your prompt attention to this important
matter
sincerely Chuck E Grassley chairman CC
